Graphical abstract The effects of Al-modification on the physico-chemical nature of surface chromate species and ethylene polymerization mechanisms over Phillips CrO x /SiO2 catalyst were studied by high-resolution XPS, ethylene polymerization and DFT method. In this work, the effects of Al-modification on Phillips catalysts were investigated by high-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and the performance in ethylene polymerization reactions. Density functional theory (DFT) method was used to achieve a deeper mechanistic understanding. The decreased Cr 2p binding energies (BE), related with an increase in electron density of chromium by Al-modification, have been confirmed by the DFT calculation. The ethylene polymerization activity over the Al-modified Phillips catalyst was increased. The molecular weight (MW) of polymer was decreased with the expansion of molecular weight distribution (MWD) to low MW side, which was in agreement with the decreased energy barrier difference between the chain transfer and chain propagation in DFT calculation. The initiation step undergoing a metallacycle reaction pathway was found through a spin crossover from the quintet energy surface via a minimum energy crossing point (MECP) to the triplet energy surface. Modeling results indicated that the promotion effect on polymerization activity from Al-modification for Phillips catalyst was mainly originated from the chain initiation reaction with lowered energy barrier for Al-modified Cr active sites. Improved environmental stress-crack resistance (ESCR) of polymer derived from the Al-modified catalyst could be expected from the less short chain branches (SCBs) distribution in the low MW side. Keywords Phillips CrO x /SiO2 catalyst Al-modification X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Density functional theory Spin-crossover 1 Introduction Phillips CrO x /SiO2 catalyst has been long among the most widely used industrial polyethylene catalysts since its discovery by Hogan and Banks in the early 1950s [1,2]. Currently, its high-density polyethylene (HDPE) products account for about 40% of the global market [3]. The majority of HDPE produced by Phillips catalysts are applied to manufacture blow-molded hollow containers and extruded pipes, owing to the peculiar structural characteristics of ultra-broad molecular weight distribution (MWD) and long-chain branching in contrast to the HDPE products by Ziegler-Natta and metallocene catalysts. In the long course of development during the last half century, this successful commercial catalyst has attracted great deal of both industrial and academic research interests [4–11]. But the contribution in academic studies has been advanced more slowly than the progress of industrial application. Despite recent significant progress in mechanistic understanding, precise relationships between catalyst structures and its resulting polymer properties have not yet been achieved. Conventional Phillips polymerization catalyst is prepared by impregnating an aqueous solution of chromium compound, usually Cr(III) acetate, onto high-surface-area amorphous silica carrier and then calcining in a non-reducing atmosphere like dry air or oxygen to activate the catalyst (500–900°C). In the period of thermal activation, chromium species is stably anchored and highly dispersed on the extensive silica–gel surface by reacting with its hydroxyl groups to form complex surface Cr(VI) species, the precursors of the real active sites. The molecular structures of the precursors of Cr active sites, the polymerization kinetics and the properties of polymer product are extremely sensitive to any small change in the preparation conditions, such as modifying silica support or changing calcination procedure. For this reason, great effort has been made to modify the original Phillips CrO x /SiO2 catalyst chemically by introducing titanium, aluminum, fluoride, etc. [6,12,13]. Although the oxidation state of the active site, the exact polymerization mechanism and the molecular structure of the catalyst still remained controversial, the development and commercialization of a number of modified Phillips catalysts have never stopped aiming at fulfilling various requirements of different polymer grades. In order to improve the branching control ability of Phillips catalyst for polyethylene, a series of hybrid Phillips catalyst modified by a second metal oxide were also reported by Matta et al. [14]. More recently, we reported a series of bimetallic catalysts modified from the traditional UCC S-2 catalyst for making polyethylene and ethylene/1-hexene copolymers with bimodal molecular weight distribution together with improved short-chain-branch distribution [15,16]. Al-modified Phillips catalyst serves as one kind of important industrial polyethylene catalysts. However, this distinctive commercial Al-modified Phillips catalyst has not been widely investigated yet. Actually, there are only a few papers about the modification of Phillips catalysts with aluminum compounds, and most of them are early patent applications. Al-modification is usually accomplished by surface impregnation method. Small amounts of aluminum compound like aluminum alkoxides, alkyl aluminum alkoxides, alkyl aluminum, alkyl or aryl aluminum halides and aryl aluminum are introduced to the pre-dried silica–gel before or after or even simultaneously with the impregnation of chromium but prior to the calcination step. As a consequence, an aluminum coating (perhaps Al2O3 layer) could be obtained in the simplest method and therefore chromium is allowed to link to the aluminum in the following thermal activation process at high temperatures. The first systematical study on the influence of Al-modification with different Al source and Al content on the ethylene polymerization over Phillips catalyst was carried out by Reker et al. [17]. It was found that Al-modification resulted in an increase in polymerization activity and a higher polymer melting index (MI). Similar conclusions were also reported in subsequent related patents [18–25]. Besides, enhancement of environmental stress-crack resistance (ESCR) was also claimed for products from Al-modified catalyst [24,25]. Furthermore, McDaniel [6] reported that the MWD of polymers made with Al-modified Phillips catalyst activated at 500°C was much similar to that produced by Al-free catalyst except for the presence of a small low MW fraction. It was suggested that those Cr sites which were closely associated with aluminum mainly produce low MW polymer. In summary, the promotion effect of polymerization activity, expansion of MWD of polymer to lower MW region, and enhanced ESCR property could occur due to the Al-modification for the Phillips catalyst. However, no investigation has ever been reported into explaining the mechanism of these Al-modification effects at the molecular level. In recent decades, an efficient approach combining experimental techniques with quantum chemical calculation has been rapidly developed and thus makes it feasible to study both the catalytic mechanism and energetics of olefin polymerization and/or oligomerization reactions [8]. Models of heterogeneous Phillips catalysts for ethylene polymerization, acetylene cyclotrimerization, and homogeneous catalysts for ethylene oligomerization have been studied in our precious work [26–30]. Based on the spectroscopic characterization and molecular modeling, Demmelmaier et al. [31] studied the chromasiloxane ring size effect in Phillips catalyst and claimed that the 6-membered chromasiloxane rings showed high polymerization rate. Moreover, multi-technique approach was adopted by Estephane et al. [32] to study a spin flip reaction from Cp2Cr to Cp2Cr(CO) adduct. The ground spin states according to different density functional theory (DFT) functionals agreed with the paramagnetic NMR observation of spin flip from the paramagnetic reagent (triplet state) to the diamagnetic product (singlet state). More recently, we have made an endeavor to adopt high resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and DFT method in studying the effects of Ti-modification of Phillips catalyst [33] on the polymerization activity and microstructure of corresponding polymer. DFT calculation substantiated the electron-withdrawing effect of Ti-modification on surface Cr(VI) species, coinciding with XPS observation that the binding energy (BE) value of the Cr 2p core level increased with the increase in Ti contents. To the best of our knowledge, no molecular modeling investigation of Al-modification on Phillips catalyst has been reported up to now. In this work, high-resolution XPS characterization was carried out to investigate the variation in the electronic environment on the surface chromate species induced by Al-modification on the Phillips catalyst. Additionally, DFT method was used at molecular level understanding the promotion effects of Al-modification with respect to the increased polymerization activity, extension of MWD to lower MW region, and enhancement of ESCR. The combined theoretical and experimental probe into the effects of Al-modification on the Phillips catalyst aimed at a deeper insight into the mechanistic understanding of the effects of Al-modification. 2 Experimental and computational 2.1 Catalysts Six industrial Phillips catalysts with or without Al-modification were all donated from PQ Corp., USA. Taking the confidential reason into consideration, only a simplified introduction of the preparation procedures of these catalysts was given. Surface impregnation method is utilized for Al-modification of Phillips catalyst in this work [22]. For Al-modified samples, a dichloromethane solution of aluminum acetylacetonate was impregnated onto the silica support (Grade MS-3050 silica–gel with BET surface area of 480–550m2/g, pore volumes of 3.0mL/g, average pore diameter of 24nm, average particle size of 90μm, pre-dried at 300°C) for 4h at room temperature, and then dried at 120°C for 6h followed by calcination at 550°C for 4h in a quartz fluidized bed at highly purified air atmosphere. And then, the obtained aluminum-modified silica was further impregnated with an aqueous solution of chromium acetate for 4h at room temperature followed by drying at 120°C for 6h. Finally, the dried Al-modified chromium samples were thermally-activated at given calcination temperatures for 4h. Two different calcination temperatures, 650 and 820°C, were employed to study the activation temperature effect at equivalent surface aluminum concentrations. Al-free catalyst samples were the traditional Phillips catalysts skipping the foregoing impregnation of Al-compound. Thereby all catalyst samples with different final calcination temperatures and Al contents were classified into two series: PhA-1 (0wt.% Al), PhA-2 (2.28wt.% Al), and PhA-3 (3.34wt.% Al) activated at 650°C, and PhB-1 (0wt.% Al), PhB-2 (2.28wt.% Al), PhB-3 (3.34wt.% Al) activated at 820°C. In fact, the Al-free PhA-1 and PhB-1 samples were just the same catalysts marked as Ph-3 and Ph-6, respectively, in our previous publication [33]. The aluminum and chromium content, and the textural properties including BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of the catalysts, which were measured at −196°C using N2 after evacuating the catalysts at 300°C for 1h, were listed in Table 1 . Two Phillips catalysts without or with Al-modification, named as Cr/SiO2 and Cr/Al-SiO2, were prepared in our laboratory for comparison according to the same procedure mentioned-above. The two catalysts were thermally-activated at 600°C. The Cr and Al loading were 1wt.% and 2.28wt.%, respectively. 2.2 High-resolution XPS characterization of catalysts High-resolution XPS characterization was performed on a Physical Electronics PerkinElmer Model Phi-5600 ESCA spectrometer using a monochromated Al Kα radiation X-ray source (E =1486.6eV) operated at 300W. Before entering the XPS apparatus, all samples were put into a vacuum transfer vessel (Phi Model 04-110, PerkinElmer Co., Ltd.) in a glove box, which could be connected to the sample introduction chamber on the XPS instrument for sample transfer without atmospheric exposure. All binding energies (BE) were referred to the Si 2p peak of silica–gel at 103.3eV for the charging effect correction [34]. For determining the BE and quantitative analysis, multiplet fittings of the peaks of Cr 2p XPS spectra were implemented using Gaussian–Lorentzian method. More details could be found in Refs. [34,35]. 2.3 Ethylene polymerization and characterization of polymers Two Cr/SiO2 and Cr/Al-SiO2 catalyst samples prepared in our laboratory were utilized for a comparison of the kinetic behavior of ethylene polymerization. The polymerization was carried out in a three-neck flask, which was placed at a thermostatic bath keeping at 85°C. One small ampoule tube with 160±5mg catalyst, which was previously weighed and sealed in nitrogen at a glove box, was carefully transferred to the flask. The reactor system was heated and vacuumed for 0.5h, and then 70mL n-heptane was added followed by introducing a certain amount of tri-isobutyl aluminum (TiBA, Al/Cr molar ratios=2.5). Ethylene passed through three columns containing activated 13X, copper and 4A molecular sieves in sequence to remove traces of water and O2 and was then introduced up to the total pressure of 0.15MPa into the preheated flask. The polymerization was initiated after opening the sealed catalyst tube. The real-time ethylene consumption was continuously monitored by an on-line mass flowmeter (Brooks Instrument 0150E). After 1h, the polymerization was stopped, and the reaction product was transported to 100mL ethanol/HCl solution as terminating agent. The obtained polymer was washed and dried in vacuum at 60°C for 6h before weighed. The molecular weight (MW) and molecular weight distribution (MWD) of the polyethylene were obtained using a PL220 high-temperature chromatography unit with trichlorobenzene (TCB) as the solvent at a flow rate of 1mL/min at 160°C. 2,6-di-tert-Butyl-4-methylphenol (BHT) at a concentration of 0.025g/L was used as a stabilizer in the TCB. The polymer was dissolved to the concentration of 1mg/mL in stabilized TCB by heating at 160°C for 5h with continuous, gentle agitation. The differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) experiments were performed on TA Q200 under N2 atmosphere. The melting point temperature (Tm) program was that the temperature was up to 150°C with 10°C/min and kept for 5min then cooled down to 40°C to eliminate the heat history. Finally the temperature was up to 150°C again at the heating rate of 10°C/min and the DSC curves were collected. 2.4 Computational details 2.4.1 Computational method All the theoretical calculations were performed with the Gaussian 03 software package [36] using UB3LYP hybrid DFT method, which included three-parameter gradient-corrected exchange functional of Becke [37] in combination with the nonlocal correlation functional of Lee et al. [38]. The basis set employed was the LANL2TZ(f) (a triple-ξ quality basis set, the Hay–Wadt relativistic effective core potential (RECP) as implemented in LANL2DZ [39] associated with revised basis set [40]) for Cr and the 6-311G(d, p) basis set for the rest main group atoms including C, H, O, Si and Al. Such combination of basis sets has been adopted in order to perform efficient and accurate calculations. The stationary structures were optimized without any symmetry constraints. Harmonic vibrational analysis was carried out at the same level of theory for structural optimization to confirm that transition states had only one imaginary frequency while stationary points (reactant and product) had no imaginary frequency. The intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations [41,42] were performed to verify the connections between the transition states and the corresponding minimums. The NBO program implemented in Gaussian 03 was used to obtain natural populations of atoms to study the chemical bonding characteristics [43]. All energies reported referred to Gibbs free energy corrections to the total electronic energies at gas phase, 298.15K and 1 atmospheric pressure. 2.4.2 Cluster models Six mononuclear chromium cluster models were proposed for the DFT calculation as presented in Scheme 1 . After calcination of catalyst, chromium is considered to be present as Cr(VI)O x,surf species with two oxygen linking to the silica surface, dominantly in the type of chromate at low Cr loading. Moreover, Cr(II)O x,surf species is believed to be the main chromium active site precursor of pre-reduced Phillips catalyst. Hence, based on the efficiency of simplified heterogeneous cluster models of Phillips catalyst adopted in the literatures [33,43–47], mononuclear chromium(VI) model (denoted as A0 in Scheme 1) and mononuclear chromium(II) model (denoted as A1 in Scheme 1) were employed as calcined Cr(VI) site and pre-reduced Cr(II) site models, respectively, for the Al-free Phillips catalyst. To the best of our knowledge, no Al-modified Phillips catalyst models have ever been proposed before. After all, reaction of aluminum compound with surface OH possibly generates Si–O–Al linkages [48] and the following impregnation of chromium would form Cr–O–Al linkages. Several 6-membered ring cluster models containing Mo–O–Al bridge have been established for MoO x /Al2O3 catalyst in our previous work [44] and successfully elucidated the influences of Mo oxidation state and surface hydroxyl on the polymerization activity. As the structure of precursor site and polymerization kinetics are similar for chromium based catalyst and molybdenum based catalyst, calcined sites of Al-modified Phillips catalyst could similarly be designated as hexa-valent Cr cluster models B0 and C0 with Al/Cr ratio of 1:1 and 2:1, respectively. Correspondingly, pre-reduced active site precursors could be designated as divalent Cr cluster models B1 and C1 with Al/Cr ratio of 1:1 and 2:1, respectively. Generally, three kinds of surface Cr site models were established marked as A, B, and C, taking into account all the possible Al-modification environments on the Phillips catalyst in our theoretical calculations. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 High-resolution XPS study on the effects of Al-modification and calcination temperature In this part of work, all six PhA and PhB Phillips catalyst samples with 0, 2.28, and 3.34wt.% Al contents at two different calcination temperatures of 650 and 820°C, respectively, were characterized by high-resolution XPS measurement. The XPS spectra of Cr 2p core level for all samples in dependence on XPS acquisition time from 10 to 30 and 120min were all shown in Figs. S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information. All spectra consisted of two main doublet features corresponding to Cr 2p3/2 and Cr 2p1/2 photoelectrons. The BE values of Cr 2p3/2 level around 580 and 577eV were assigned to be Cr(VI)O x,surf and Cr(III)O x,surf species, respectively [35]. The information (corresponding BE, FWHM values) of the Cr 2p3/2 core level, assignment and atomic percentage of different oxidation states of surface Cr species for all catalyst samples versus XPS acquisition time obtained after peak deconvolution and multiplet fitting are tabulated in Tables 2 and S1 in the Supporting Information. As shown in Table 2, the XPS data obtained at acquisition time of 10min could identify the original physico-chemical natures of surface chromate species [33,49] with negligible photo-reduction of surface chromate species induced by soft X-ray irradiation during XPS measurement. For catalysts PhA-1, PhA-2, and PhA-3 calcined at 650°C, it was found that the BE values for chromate species were gradually decreased from 580.60 to 580.52 and 580.18eV with increasing Al content from 0 to 3.34wt.%. For catalysts PhB-1, PhB-2 and PhB-3 calcined at 820°C, the BE values for chromate species were also gradually decreased from 580.79 to 580.57 and 580.30eV with increasing Al content from 0 to 3.34wt.%. Such BE data obtained in 10min XPS measurement illuminated two aspects of electronic effects of Al-modification. Firstly, no significant shifting of Cr 2p peak to lower BE value was detected within 10min, demonstrating only Cr(VI)O x,surf species existed on the original Phillips catalyst surface whether with or without Al-modification. Secondly, the slight decrease tendency of BE value implied that the electron-deficiency of surface chromate species decreased along with an increase in Al content for the Al-modified Phillips catalysts, probably owing to the lower electro negativity of aluminum atoms. However, it is interesting to note that the latter seems to be contradictory to the promotion effect of Al-modification on polymerization activity as mentioned before because increasing the electron density on chromium atom generally leads to an decrease in polymerization rate, as reported by McDaniel [50] and Marsden [51]. On the other hand, it might imply that the promotion effect from Al-modification could be derived from different mechanism compared with the promotion effect from Ti-modification for the Phillips catalyst as demonstrated in our previous report [33]. For PhA catalysts series which were calcined at 650°C, FWHM first increased from 4.90 (PhA-1) to 5.40eV (PhA-2) and then deceased back to 4.90eV (PhA-3), indicating a broader distribution of surface chromate species by modest Al-modification while the high Al content would conversely restrain such effect. As expected, for the PhB catalyst series calcined at a higher temperature of 820°C, FWHM first increased from 5.80 to 6.29eV and then decreased to 5.90eV with Al loading from 0 to 2.28 and 3.34wt.%, respectively. After Al-modification, the BE value for chromate species was decreased, while the case for Ti-modified catalyst was just on the opposite situation. Our previous XPS study found that Ti-modification led to an increase in the BE value for chromate species [33]. As the corresponding polymerization activities were similarly increased for both Al-modified and Ti-modified Phillips catalysts, further mechanistic investigation should be performed in order to make this issue clearer. When XPS acquisition time was prolonged to 30 and 120min, it was found that partial labile Cr(VI)O x,surf species could be converted into Cr(III)O x,surf species due to the photo-reduction from the soft X-ray irradiation during XPS measurement. Table S1 in the Supporting Information listed all 30 and 120min XPS characterization data, from which the photo stability of the surface chromate species versus Al-modification could be observed. The photo stability of surface chromate species during XPS measurement was enhanced by Al-modification and the formation of Cr(III)O x,surf species from the reduction of Cr(VI)O x,surf species was accordingly retarded by Al-modification during XPS acquisition. The effect of calcination temperature on catalyst physico-chemical property could be elucidated by comparing BE values of the PhA series activated at 650°C with those of the PhB series activated at 820°C. When the calcination temperature increasing from 650 to 820°C, the Cr 2p3/2 BE values of the Cr(VI)O x,surf species on Al-free catalysts increased from 580.60eV for PhA-1 to 580.79eV for PhB-1. And the corresponding FWHM broadened from 4.90 to 5.80eV, as shown in Table 2. It was the direct evidence for increased electron-deficiency of chromium center and broadened distribution of surface chromate species, which could be ascribed to the removal of more electron-donating surface residual hydroxyl groups and the increase in surface tension due to dehydroxylation at higher calcination temperatures [49]. Moreover, similar phenomenon has also been observed between the sample pairs of PhA-2 and PhB-2, PhA-3 and PhB-3, after Al-modification. It was suggested that the Al-modification could not release the temperature effect on the electronic property of the chromate species on Phillips catalyst. That is to say, the higher calcination temperature leads to the higher electron-deficiency of the surface chromate species regardless of the presence of Al. In general, XPS measurement clearly signified that Al-modification enhanced the photo stability of surface chromate species and accordingly retard the formation of Cr(III)O x,surf species from the reduction of Cr(VI)O x,surf species during XPS acquisition. However, the observed decreased BE values showed an increase in electron density of chromium center by Al-modification for the Phillips catalyst. This effect was presumably attributed to the lower electro negativity of the surrounding aluminum atoms. 3.2 Effect of Al-modification on polymerization activity and MW of polymer In this work, the Al-free Phillips catalyst Cr/SiO2 and Al-modified Phillips catalyst Cr/Al-SiO2 were used for ethylene homo-polymerization in the presence of TiBA cocatalyst at Al/Cr molar ratio=2.5 (cocatalyst is not needed in industry, but it is necessary in laboratory experiment to shorten the induction period of reducing Cr(VI) into a lower valence state under the atmospheric pressure and also to remove the traces of O2 and moisture) [52]. Kinetics behaviors for the Cr/SiO2 and Cr/Al-SiO2 shown in Fig. 1 were in two different types like the typical kinetic curves of ethylene homopolymerization reactions: (a) the Al-modified Phillips catalyst led to higher activity and faster decay and (b) the traditional Phillips catalyst showed relatively lower activity but slower decay [53,54]. The catalytic activity was increased from 131.6kg PE/molCr h (Cr/SiO2) to 156.6kg PE/molCr h (Cr/Al-SiO2) after Al-modification as shown in Table 3 . More importantly, the real-time kinetics curves of catalysts, Cr/SiO2 and Cr/Al-SiO2, illustrated that Al-modified Phillips catalyst underwent a longer induction time. The observed longer induction time might be explained from the increased electron density of Cr(VI) sites after Al-modification, which is evidently adverse to not only the coordination of ethylene molecules to chromium sites but also the further electron exchange between the coordinated ethylene and chromium center. The melting point temperatures (Tm) of polymer products from both catalysts were similar at about 131°C. Additionally, a decline of the MW of HDPE product from 328,000g/mol (Cr/SiO2) to 250,000g/mol (Cr/Al-SiO2) was noticed after Al-modification. So it was speculated that the Al-modification plausibly promote the formation of the low MW fraction which was consistent with the differences of the molecular weight distributions between the products by the Al-modified and Al-free Phillips catalysts as shown in Fig. 2 . The MW of the polymer obtained from Cr/Al-SiO2 was shifted to the lower MW region. Deeper mechanistic understanding on the effects of Al-modification will be demonstrated by the following DFT study. 3.3 DFT calculation of Al-modification effects on polymerization activity Phillips catalyst is a kind of “metal-alkyl-free” polymerization catalyst. The activation could be accomplished by self-alkylation without a metal alkyl co-catalyst. After contacting with reductant (mostly using C2H4 in industry), the Cr(VI)O x,surf species of prepared catalyst precursors are expected to be reduced to Cr(II)O x,surf analogs for initiating further ethylene polymerization. The hexa-valent chromate precursors (Cr(VI)O x,surf sites) were modeled by three mononuclear chromium cluster models (denoted as A0, B0, C0 presented in Scheme 1) with 0, 1, or 2Cr-O-Al bridges, respectively. The pre-reduced divalent chromium species (Cr(II)O x,surf sites) after reduction step were similarly modeled by three clusters denoted as A1, B1, and C1 presented in Scheme 1. On the basis of these cluster models, a systematic DFT investigation on Al-modification to Phillips catalyst with respect to corresponding promotion of polymerization activity, extension of MWD to lower MW region and enhancement of ESCR was put into practice. Firstly, the promotion effect on polymerization activity from Al-modification for the Phillips catalyst was studied. The reduction of chromate species, chain initiation on reduced divalent chromium sites and chain propagation on active sites were generally figured as the determining factors of the activity of Phillips catalyst. Geometry parameters and Natural Bond Orbital (NBO) charge for Cr(VI) site models and Cr(II) site models are listed in Table 4 . The most pronounced difference of geometry parameters was found in terms of ∠O1-Cr-O2 angle. For the Cr(VI) site models, this bond angle increased from A0 to B0 and C0. While in the case of the reduced Cr(II) site models, it also opened from A1 to B1 and C1. The wider ∠O1-Cr-O2 indicated that the Al-modified cluster was more strained. Apart from the O1-Cr-O2 bond angle, the bond lengths of CrO differed by about 0.01Å in the Cr–O–Al moiety compared with slightly longer CrO bond in the Cr–O–Si moiety. The key point to note was the significant decreasing NBO charge on Cr(VI) and on Cr(II). The decrease in NBO charge value on chromium for cluster models B and C involving aluminum atoms demonstrated an increase in electron density of Cr site with Al-modification, which was consistent with the decrease in BE value of surface chromate species after Al-modification by XPS characterization as mentioned before. This consistency was also a direct evidence for the validity and reasonableness of our proposed cluster models for our DFT calculations. Obviously, since the increase in electron density of chromium on Cr(VI) sites after Al-modification hindered not only the coordination of ethylene but also the electron transfer from coordinated ethylene to Cr(VI) sites, reduction of Cr(VI)O x,surf species for Al-modified catalyst would be more difficult than that for the Al-free one. According to our previous study on Cr(II)/SiO2 active site precursors in Phillips polymerization catalysts, the reaction route for the reduction of silica-supported Cr(VI) species into Cr(II) species either by ethylene or Al-alkyl cocatalyst is proposed in Scheme 2 in the initial period of ethylene polymerization [26]. The issue of how an initial monoalkylchromium structure may be generated, without any external alkylation agent to supply the first starting polymer chain, has been proven difficult to be clarified despite its importance to our basic understanding of the Phillips catalyst. The crucial initiation mechanism involving the first CrH or CrC bond formation has stimulated a great debate, among which metallacycle initiation mechanism has gained wider acceptance in recent years. FTIR spectroscopy evidence of the occurrence of metallacycle intermediate species during ethylene polymerization on the Cr(II)/SiO2 Phillips catalyst was observed using in-situ FTIR measurement by Groopo et al. [11]. Likewise, chromacyclopentane was also proposed as intermediate species as reported by Ghiotti et al. [55], Emrich et al. [56], and Ruddick and Badyal [57]. From theoretical aspect, Espelid and Børve [45–47] reported metallacycle mechanism might be the most plausible initiation mechanism according to the lowest energy barrier. Hence, in this section the DFT calculation of chain initiation step was carried out undergoing a metallacycle pathway as illustrated in Scheme 2. Global abbreviation X signified the labeling of three proposed Al-involved or Al-free cluster models (X = A, Al:Cr=0:1; X= B, Al:Cr=1:1; X =C, Al:Cr=2:1). According to metallacycle initiation mechanism, coordination of two ethylene molecules to the reduced Cr(II) active center (X1 in Scheme 2) took place to give a coordinated bis-ethylene-Cr(II) π-complex (X2 in Scheme 2) leading to the formation of a chromacyclopentane species (X3 in Scheme 2). Geometry optimization of each structure for three kinds of cluster models was conducted under all possible spin states to identify the ground spin state. The DFT calculation at B3LYP level showed that the ground spin state of X1 and X2 with divalent chromium was quintet while the ground spin state of the oxidative cyclic addition product X3 with tetravalent chromium was triplet. In this case, the chain initiation possibly involved a spin crossover between a triplet surface and a quintet surface. In theoretical studies of organometallic reactions, the limitation of calculation at a single spin state is one reason why computational calculation usually gives ambiguous results which are not consistent with experimental conclusions. Fortunately, Harvey et al. [58] has developed a DFT method to locate the crucial minimum energy crossing point (MECP) involved in such issue and this technique was adopted in our previous publication [59]. Consequently, we have studied the spin crossover phenomenon by locating MECPs between two different potential energy surfaces in order to compare the reactivity on cluster models A, B, and C with or without Al-modification over the Phillips catalyst. Calculation results of the chain initiation pathways for A, the Al-free Phillips catalyst model, on triplet and quintet surfaces are shown in Table 5 and Fig. S3 in the Supporting Information. All geometry optimizations were carried out on the following stationary points: the triplet and quintet active sites ( 3A1 and 5A1, the superscript number representing corresponding spin multiplicity employed during DFT calculation), π-complexes ( 3A2 and 5A2), MECPs on the way to the formation of five-member ring, five-member ring products ( 3A3 and 5A3) and two transition states ( 3TS[A2-A3] and 5TS[A2-A3]) leading from π-complexes to the oxidative coupling products. Energy differences were related to 3A1 and corrected with the corresponding number of ethylene molecules. On the triplet energy surface, starting from a reduced 3A1 cluster, two ethylene monomers coordinated to it giving a π-complex 3A2. This coordination step was obvious exoergic by 12.45kcal/mol ( 3A1 → 3A2). A chromacyclopentane structure 3A3 was subsequently yielded from π-complex overcoming an energy barrier of 6.34kcal/mol ( 3TS[A2-A3]). On the other hand, on the quintet surface, coordination of two ethylene was slightly exoergic by 2.75kcal/mol ( 5A1 → 5A2) and the energy barrier for the formation of five-member ring structure was calculated to be 42.41kcal/mol ( 5TS[A2-A3]). Obviously, DFT calculation results on the triplet and quintet energy surface were remarkably different in the energetic behavior. The lower energy quintet reactant 5A1 and 5A2 with four unpaired d-electrons in chromium were more stable than the triplet analog with two unpaired d-electrons in chromium. Conversely, the quintet product 5A3 and corresponding transition state 5TS[A2-A3] presented higher in energy than 3A3 and 3TS[A2-A3]. Consequently, due to the different ground spin states of stationary points along the reaction pathway, spin crossover should occur to the formation of 3A3 from π-complex 5A2. It seemed to us worthwhile to take advantage of MECP technique to identify the triplet–quintet crossing point on the pathway to the formation of chromacyclopentane. A-MECP was precisely located and computed at −10.73kcal/mol on either triplet or quintet state. The total energy barrier including the binding energy of ethylene coordination and the energetic barrier of metallacycle formation should be 22.19kcal/mol. Calculation results of the two Al-modified cluster models B and C were shown in Table 5, Fig. S4 (in the Supporting Information) and Fig. 3 . Energetic behaviors calculated were similar to those of model A. Likewise, taking spin crossover between the quintet and triplet surfaces into account, MECPs were found at −5.47kcal/mol (B-MECP) and −9.54kcal/mol (C-MECP) and the energy barriers for chain initiation on model B and C were 19.95kcal/mol and 18.50kcal/mol, respectively, both of which were lower than that for model A indicating a decreasing of energy barrier for chain initiation after Al-modification over the Phillips catalyst. In addition, it was also found that the coordination of two ethylene molecules to the Cr(II) site was endoergic by 0.29kcal/mol ( 5B1 → 5B2) and 2.44kcal/mol ( 5C1 → 5C2) on model B and C, respectively. And for model A this coordination step was exoergic by 2.75kcal/mol ( 5A1 → 5A2). As discussed before, the wider the ∠O1-Cr-O2 angle opened, the greater the strain on the reduced Cr(II) site would be. As a result, coordination of ethylene monomers to the reduced Cr(II) sites B1 and C1 would be disfavored because of the steric hindrance effect. It was interesting to contrast the above calculation results till now for the formation of chromacyclopentane(VI) from oxidative coupling of two ethylene molecules, standing for chain initiation pathway undergoing the metallacycle mechanism, on the two different spin states. For three cluster models A, B, and C, the energy barrier gradually increased when the reaction took place on the triplet surface, whereas it dramatically decreased in sequence on the quintet surface. The two contradictory conclusions were finally explained by introducing spin crossover. The plausible reaction pathways were figured out by locating MECPs between the triplet and quintet energy surfaces. Therefore the energy barrier, obtained considering spin crossover, was computed much lower on Al-modified site models B and C in contrast to Al-free site model A. So Al-modification to Phillips catalyst was proven to facilitate the chain initiation reaction on reduced Cr(II) sites by DFT calculations, where the promotion effect on polymerization activity for the Al-modified Phillips catalyst might be derived from. The frontier molecular orbitals of Cr(II) sites on various Phillips catalyst cluster models were analyzed in order to explain the difference in energetic behavior of the chain initiation reaction. Fig. 4 illustrated the frontier orbitals of Cr(II) sites 5X1 (X = A, B, C). The LUMOs (the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) of 5A1, 5B1, and 5C1 in the top row, which accepted the donation of electrons from π-bonding orbital of the ethylene monomer, were found almost the same. The bottom row showed the HOMOs (the highest occupied molecular orbital) of 5A1, 5B1, and 5C1. Higher electron density around oxygen atoms adjacent to Cr(II) on Al-modified models 5B1 and 5C1 could be recognized, which could increase the in-phase overlap of HOMO with the empty π* anti-bonding orbital of the ethylene monomer. As we know, the larger the overlap population, the easier the activation of ethylene molecule and the interaction between Cr and the incoming ethylene. Hence, the calculated lower energy barriers for chain initiation reaction on Al-modified Phillips catalyst models was well elucidated by comparing the frontier orbitals of 5A1 with 5B1 and 5C1. As one of the most commonly accepted propagation mechanism of transition metal-catalyzed olefin polymerization system, especially suitable for the Ziegler–Natta catalyst, Cossee–Arlman mechanism [60] is also generally accepted for CrO x /SiO2 system. An ethylene molecule π-coordinated to the chromium active site followed by inserting into the Cr-alkyl bond and thus the alkyl chain was extended by one monomer unit. Therefore, Cosse–Arlman mechanism was employed to study chain propagation (denoted as X4 → X5y → X6y → X7y → X8y in Scheme 3 ) on the three cluster models by DFT method. Global abbreviation y signified the labeling of substrate, ethylene or 1-butene or 1-hexene (y = a, R=H, ethylene homopolymerization; y = b, R=butyl, copolymerization with 1-hexene). The initial monoalkylchromium(III) structure was simplified as a tricoordinated chromium-methyl species X4. The energy barriers computed for chain propagation reaction (X5a → X6a and X7a → X8a) proceeding on the three proposed cluster models of the Phillips catalysts are presented in Table 6 . The energy barrier for the formation of chromium-propyl species from A5a to A6a through the first ethylene insertion step was 21.52kcal/mol on Al-free cluster A, yet the corresponding energy barriers on Al-modified cluster B and cluster C increased to 23.63 and 25.74kcal/mol, respectively. Chromium-pentyl species could be formed still undergoing the Cossee propagation path through the coordination and subsequent insertion of a second ethylene from X7a to X8a with energy barriers of 24.05kcal/mol on cluster B and 26.12kcal/mol on cluster C, both of which were also higher than that on cluster A (21.92kcal/mol). Such tendency indicated that chain propagation step was even more difficult after Al-modification for the Phillips catalysts. Fig. 5 illustrates the frontier orbitals of X4 (X = A, B, C). The top row showed the LUMOs of A4, B4 and C4. In A4, there was an obvious empty d orbital which can accept π electrons of the incoming ethylene, and thus facilitated the insertion of the ethylene into CrC bond. While such empty d orbital of Cr in B4 became unobvious and consequently the π donation was weakened. In the case of C4, the in-phase overlap and out-phase overlap of LUMO with the π orbital of ethylene were totally equal. Therefore, the π electrons of the incoming ethylene could not availably be transferred to the 3d xy orbital of Cr. Although the HOMOs of X4 exhibited similar tendency as those of X1, the interaction between ethylene and methylchromium was not just determined by such π* back donation, but dominantly by the donation of π electron from ethylene to the empty d orbital of Cr center. Therefore, for chain propagation from X4 to X5, Al-free Phillips catalyst model was energetically much more favorable than the Al-modified models. In summary, the NBO charge value on chromium calculated by DFT method demonstrated that the electron density of chromium sites increased after Al-modification, which was consistent with experimental observation of the decrease in BE value of surface chromate species after Al-modification by high resolution XPS characterization as discussed before. Considering the spin crossover between the triplet and quintet energy surfaces, Al-modification to Phillips catalyst was then proven to obviously facilitate chain initiation on the reduced Cr(II) sites undergoing the metallacycle mechanism and it was thought to be the crucial reason for the promotion effect on polymerization activity. Yet Al-modification seemed to be unfavorable for chain propagation reaction for the Phillips catalyst. 3.4 DFT calculation of Al-modification effects on the microstructures of polymer chains In this section, DFT investigation was carried out on the effect of Al-modification on the microstructures of polymer chains. Generally, the MWD is suggested to be dependent with the ratio of chain transfer rate to chain propagation rate. As Espelid and Børve [45–47] found that direct hydrogen transfer to Cr center was too difficult due to the weak Cr-hydride bond which meant hydrogen transfer preferred to occur to the incoming next monomer. Herein, chain transfer (see X7y → X9y in Scheme 3) was accomplished by β-hydride transfer to an incoming next ethylene monomer yielding polymer chain containing one methyl and one terminal vinyl ends. X7a could undergo agostic-assisted β-hydride transfer from Cβ in the Cr-CH2 α-CH2 β-CH3 γ fragment to the coordinated ethylene to yield X9a with a coordinated 1-propylene which was liberated simultaneously. Similarly, further competing propagation and chain transfer reaction could endure likewise along with the polymerization time until deactivation of the active site. The energy barriers are presented in Table 6 as computed for competing chain propagation reaction (X7a → X8a) and chain transfer reaction (X7a → X9a) proceeding on the three proposed cluster models. The energy barrier for the formation of chromium-pentyl species gradually increased with increase of Al-contents. On the other hand, after the coordination of the second ethylene, chain transfer via β-H shift from Cr-CH2CH2CH3 fragment to the second coordinated ethylene showed increasing energy barriers. The energy barrier difference between the second monomer insertion and β-hydride transfer on the three cluster models are illustrated in Table 6, denoted as “Δ”. It was found that the energy barrier differences was more decreased in Al-modified site models B and C. Such tendency qualitatively indicated an increased low MW fraction of polyethylene and therefore the MWD would be broadened to the lower MW region, which was consistent with the experimental evidence shown in Table 3 [6]. Meanwhile the unfavorable chain transfer after Al-modification could be also ascribed to the increase in the electron density on the chromium atom to diminish the driving force for agostic β-hydride coordination which was consistent with the XPS results. Most commercial grades of HDPE are actually copolymers of ethylene and other α-olefins involving 1-butene and 1-hexene. The short chain branches (SCBs) distribution alongside the polymer chain was thought as one of the most important factor influencing polymer properties. Whether the promoted ESCR by Al-modification is derived from some kind of better branching behavior or not is still uncertain. To handle this problem, in this section, 1,2-insertion of 1-hexene, in addition to two competing reactions subsequent second extra ethylene insertion and β-hydride transfer on the three site models with 0:1, 1:1, and 2:1 Al/Cr atomic ratios were studied by DFT method. The results are illustrated in Scheme 3 and summarized in Table 6. The energy barrier calculated for comonomer insertion into Cr-methyl moiety (X5y→X6y, Scheme 3, y = b, R=butyl) for model A was 23.07kcal/mol, higher than that required to overcome for the ethylene monomer insertion. This trend indicated that copolymerization with 1-hexene showed lower activity than homopolymerization, which was also confirmed by McDaniel [4] and our previous DFT work [33]. Compared with Al-free site model A, energy barriers for 1-hexene insertion were found much increased for Al-modified site models. Notice that, the incorporation of 1-hexene was inhibited by the sites which were associated with aluminum. Considering such Al-modified sites tend to produce lower MW polyethylene, less branches into the lower MW region and consequently improved the natural tendency of the distribution from traditional Phillips Cr/silica catalysts and concentrated the more short chain branches into the higher MW side, which was considered to be favorable for the ESCR property of the copolymers. From structure X6b formed through insertion of comonomer 1-hexene, one more short branch of the linear polyethylene backbone would be generated from the coordination and further insertion of an ethylene molecule into the growing chain (see X7y→X8y in Scheme 3, y = b). For Al-free site model A, lower energy barrier for ethylene insertion was found after the insertion of 1-hexene in contrast to that for the case of homopolymerization. It was nevertheless noteworthy that, for Al-modified catalyst site models the energy barrier for this reaction was higher after incorporation of 1-hexene in contrast to homopolymerization, which implied higher sensitivity for Al-modified sites to steric hindrance due to the R group. On the other hand, the π-complex X7b could undergo agostic-assisted β-hydride transfer to coordinated ethylene from the tertiary carbon introduced by comonomer insertion simultaneously (see X7y→X9y in Scheme 3, y = b). For site model A, the energy barrier for such tertiary hydride transfer was 28.44kcal/mol (A7b→A9b) after insertion of 1-hexene, lower than that required for secondary hydride transfer after ethylene insertion (29.74kcal/mol, A7a→A9a). Similarly, for Al-modified site models B and C, chain transfer proceeded with β-hydride shift after comonomer insertion also showed lower energy barrier than homopolymerization. Such increased chain transfer rate tendency might be a consequence of increased level of tertiary hydrides when active sites accepted comonomer insertion. In order to obtain the information of SCBs distribution in polymer chains obtained by copolymerization with 1-hexene, the difference in energy barriers between extra ethylene insertion (X7b→X8b in Scheme 3) and alternative chain transfer (X7b→X9b in Scheme 3) was also calculated as in homopolymerization. After adding comonomer, the difference in energy barriers between further ethylene insertion and tertiary β-hydrogen transfer in each model all decreased, but it decreased more in Al-modified site model B and C than Al-free site model A (see Table 6, column “Δ”). That meant the tertiary β-hydrogen transfer after the incorporation of 1-hexene into polymer chains grown on Al-modified Cr sites was accelerated, especially for Cr sites directly linked to two aluminum atoms. Taking the aforementioned observation of preference for producing lower MW polyethylene on Al-modified sites into account, much less short chain branches would be generated in the lower MW fraction due to the obviously stimulated chain transfer after comonomer insertion, leaving the inserted comonomer at the chain end. Hence, again, it was proven that less SCBs should be placed in the lower MW side of the MW distribution. Such improvement of less SCBs in the lower MW region was regarded as an efficient way to enhance polymer properties including ESCR in industrial applications. So, the experimental observation that ESCR of polyethylene made by Al-modified Phillips catalyst was much higher than that by Al-free Phillips catalyst was theoretically explained well through DFT calculation results on the basis of the three types of site models A, B and C. 4 Conclusions In this work, a systematic investigation on the effects of Al-modification on the Phillips catalyst with respect to corresponding promotion of polymerization activity, extension of MWD to lower MW region and enhancement of ESCR property was performed through theoretical calculation by DFT method on polymerization mechanism in combination with experimental high-resolution XPS characterization on the physico-chemical nature of surface Cr species and ethylene polymerization reactions. The XPS studies signified that Al-modification enhanced the photo stability of surface chromate species and therefore restricted the formation of Cr(III)O x,surf species resulted from reduction of Cr(VI)O x,surf species during XPS measurement. However, the observed decreased BE values showed a decrease in electron-deficiency (or an increase in electron density) of surface chromate species by Al-modification. The ethylene polymerization activity of the Al-modified Phillips catalyst was increased and the molecular weight (MW) of polymer was lower with the expansion of molecular weight distribution (MWD) to the low MW side. A deeper theoretical mechanism has been elucidated through employing the DFT method by investigating energetic behaviors of chain initiation, propagation and transfer proceeding on the three established cluster models with 0:1, 1:1, and 2:1 Al/Cr atomic ratios representing Phillips catalysts without or with Al-modification. Initiation reaction undergoing a metallacycle mechanism was calculated to proceed from the quintet potential energy surface via a minimum energy crossing point to the triplet potential energy surface and such spin crossover was proven by locating MECPs along the reaction pathways. Corresponding computation results confirmed that Al-associated active sites tended to decrease the energy barrier for chain initiation step when taking spin crossover into account, indicating Al-modification favored to initiate olefin polymerization on Cr(II) centers. Although both chain propagation and transfer in homopolymerization were found to be unfavorable after Al-modification, the difference in energy barriers between such two competing reactions decreased due to Al-modification, suggesting low MW polymer was preferred to produce on chromium sites containing CrOAl bond, giving rise to an expansion of MWD to the low MW side. Al-modified catalyst enhanced ESCR property of polymer due to putting less SCBs into the low MW side of the distribution in two ways: (i) retarding the incorporation of comonomer in the low MW polymer; and (ii) increasing chain transfer rate after the incorporation of comonomer. It is still not known whether the observed increase in activity is also a consequence of an increase in the number of active sites by the Al-modification. More investigation will be done in order to get closer to a complete understanding on this issue in the further work. coredata.dc:description: In this work, the effects of Al-modification on Phillips catalysts were investigated by high-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and the performance in ethylene polymerization reactions. Density functional theory (DFT) method was used to achieve a deeper mechanistic understanding. The decreased Cr 2p binding energies (BE), related with an increase in electron density of chromium by Al-modification, have been confirmed by the DFT calculation. The ethylene polymerization activity over the Al-modified Phillips catalyst was increased. The molecular weight (MW) of polymer was decreased with the expansion of molecular weight distribution (MWD) to low MW side, which was in agreement with the decreased energy barrier difference between the chain transfer and chain propagation in DFT calculation. The initiation step undergoing a metallacycle reaction pathway was found through a spin crossover from the quintet energy surface via a minimum energy crossing point (MECP) to the triplet energy surface. Modeling results indicated that the promotion effect on polymerization activity from Al-modification for Phillips catalyst was mainly originated from the chain initiation reaction with lowered energy barrier for Al-modified Cr active sites. Improved environmental stress-crack resistance (ESCR) of polymer derived from the Al-modified catalyst could be expected from the less short chain branches (SCBs) distribution in the low MW side.
